==Deaths==

[[File:Martyrs memorial in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|A memorial in Tahrir Square made by the demonstrators in honor of those who died during the protests, regarded as ''[[Shahid|shuhada']]'' Ø´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡ â "martyrs" â in Egyptian parlance. The captions in the pictures attribute most of the deaths to police violence.]]
Leading up to the protests, at least six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself on fire in downtown Cairo.<ref name="Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast">{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|work=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> These cases were inspired by, and began exactly one month after, the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia triggering the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising]]. Six instances have been reported, including acts by Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Farouk Hassan,<ref name="Mohammed Farouk Hassan">{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians Set Themselves Ablaze After Tunisia Unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Ashour Sorour,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elaosboa.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|date=18 January 2011|work=[[El-Aosboa]] (newspaper)|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed who later died from his injuries.<ref name="Ahmed Hashim El-Sayyid2">{{cite web
Leading up to the protests, at least six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself on fire in downtown Cairo.<ref name="Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast">{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|work=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> These cases were inspired by, and began exactly one month after, the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia triggering the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising]]. Six instances have been reported, including acts by Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Farouk Hassan,<ref name="Mohammed Farouk Hassan">{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians Set Themselves Ablaze After Tunisia Unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Ashour Sorour,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elaosboa.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|date=18 January 2011|work=[[El-Aosboa]] (newspaper)|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed who later died from his injuries.<ref name="Ahmed Hashim El-Sayyid2">{{cite web
Line 307: Line 307:
Funerals for the dead on the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January.<!--from tv--> Hundreds of mourners gathered for the funerals calling for Mubarak's removal.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nolan, Dan|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html|title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> By 1 February, the protests had left at least 125 people dead,<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8293442/Egypt-crisis-country-braced-for-march-of-a-million.html|title=Egypt Crisis: Country Braced for 'March of a Million' |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=31 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> although Human Rights Watch said that UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Navi Pillay]] claimed that as many as 300 people may have died in the unrest. This unconfirmed tally included 80 Human Rights Watch-verified deaths at two Cairo hospitals, 36 in Alexandria, and 13 in the port city of Suez, amongst others;<ref name="latimes1">{{cite web|author=Carol J. Williams |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html |title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="allvoices1">{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8060066-egypt-unrest-claimed-about-300-lives-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-navi-pillay|title=Egypt Unrest Claimed About 300 Lives â UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillay|publisher=Allvoices.com|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="haaretz2">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/un-human-rights-chief-300-reported-dead-in-egypt-protests-1.340583?localLinksEnabled=false|title=UN Human Rights Chief: 300 Reported Dead in Egypt Protests|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> over 3,000 people were also reported as injured.<ref name="latimes1" /><ref name="allvoices1" /><ref name="haaretz2" />
Funerals for the dead on the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January.<!--from tv--> Hundreds of mourners gathered for the funerals calling for Mubarak's removal.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nolan, Dan|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html|title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> By 1 February, the protests had left at least 125 people dead,<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8293442/Egypt-crisis-country-braced-for-march-of-a-million.html|title=Egypt Crisis: Country Braced for 'March of a Million' |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=31 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> although Human Rights Watch said that UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Navi Pillay]] claimed that as many as 300 people may have died in the unrest. This unconfirmed tally included 80 Human Rights Watch-verified deaths at two Cairo hospitals, 36 in Alexandria, and 13 in the port city of Suez, amongst others;<ref name="latimes1">{{cite web|author=Carol J. Williams |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html |title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="allvoices1">{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8060066-egypt-unrest-claimed-about-300-lives-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-navi-pillay|title=Egypt Unrest Claimed About 300 Lives â UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillay|publisher=Allvoices.com|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="haaretz2">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/un-human-rights-chief-300-reported-dead-in-egypt-protests-1.340583?localLinksEnabled=false|title=UN Human Rights Chief: 300 Reported Dead in Egypt Protests|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> over 3,000 people were also reported as injured.<ref name="latimes1" /><ref name="allvoices1" /><ref name="haaretz2" />
{{2011 Egyptian protests Death Toll}}
{{2011 Egyptian protests Death Toll}}
â
===Domestic responses===
+
  +
==International reactions==
  +
{{Main|International reactions to the Egyptian Revolution of 2011}}
  +   +
International reactions have varied with most Western states saying peaceful protests should continue but also expressing concern for the stability of the country and the region. Many states in the region expressed concern and supported Mubarak, while others like Tunisia and Iran supported the protests. Israel was most cautious for change, with [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] asking his government ministers to maintain silence and urging Israel's US and European allies to curb their criticism of President Mubarak;<ref>{{cite news|title=Israel's Big Fears over a Post-Mubarak Egypt|url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/01/31/israels-big-fears-over-a-post-mubarak-egypt/|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[Euronews]]|date=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Israel Urges World To Curb Criticism of Egypt's Mubarak|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/israel-urges-world-to-curb-criticism-of-egypt-s-mubarak-1.340238|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=31 January 2011}}</ref> however, an [[Arab-Israeli]] parliamentarian supported the protests. There were also numerous solidarity protests for the anti-government protesters around the world.
  +   +
NGOs also expressed concern about the protests and the ensuing heavy-handed state response. Many countries also issued travel warnings or began evacuating their citizens. Even [[multinational corporation]]s began evacuating their [[expatriate]] workers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/|title=Foreign governments, businesses begin evacuations from Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
===Post-ousting===
  +
Amid the growing concerns for the country, on 21 February, [[David Cameron]], Prime Minister of the [[United Kingdom]], became the first world leader to visit Egypt since Mubarak was ousted as the president 10 days previously. A news blackout was lifted as the prime minister landed in Cairo for a brief five-hour stopover hastily added at the start of a planned tour of the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd |title=David Cameron visits Egypt â The Guardian |publisher=www.guardian.co.uk |accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
==Domestic responses==
{{main|Domestic responses to the Egyptian Revolution of 2011}}
{{main|Domestic responses to the Egyptian Revolution of 2011}}
[[File:MubarakBurnsEgypt.jpg|thumb|"Nero burned Rome; Mubarak is burning Egypt"]]
[[File:MubarakBurnsEgypt.jpg|thumb|"Nero burned Rome; Mubarak is burning Egypt"]]
Line 329: Line 329:
On 13 February, an article in the state-controlled newspaper, [[Al-Ahram]], questioned the inclinations of [[Google|Google Inc.]] and its executive and activist, [[Wael Ghonim]], due to certain translation errors when using the Google Translate engine that were perceived as dubious by some.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://gate.ahram.org.eg/News/39710.aspx|title=Al-Ahram: Google translation sparks disappointment at Wael Ghoneim|author=Sara Ne'mat-Allah|date=13 February 2011|publisher-Al-Ahram}}</ref> One reported error was translating any fictitious phrase along the lines of "... occupies Israel" in Arabic into "Israel occupies..." in English. [[Google Translate]] is a [[Statistical machine translation|statistical translation engine]] that [[Google Translate#Translation mistakes and oddities|uses web search statistics rather than grammatical rules to yield a probable translation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0809/technology-computer-learning-google-translate.html|title=Forbes: Google Translate tangles with computer learning|author=Lee Gomes|date=July 22, 2010|publisher-Forbes}}</ref> Since "...occupies Israel" is a low-probability query owing to the fact that Israel has not been occupied and "Israel occupies..." is a higher-probability query on the other hand, the limitation of statistical translation results in the inaccurate translation.
On 13 February, an article in the state-controlled newspaper, [[Al-Ahram]], questioned the inclinations of [[Google|Google Inc.]] and its executive and activist, [[Wael Ghonim]], due to certain translation errors when using the Google Translate engine that were perceived as dubious by some.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://gate.ahram.org.eg/News/39710.aspx|title=Al-Ahram: Google translation sparks disappointment at Wael Ghoneim|author=Sara Ne'mat-Allah|date=13 February 2011|publisher-Al-Ahram}}</ref> One reported error was translating any fictitious phrase along the lines of "... occupies Israel" in Arabic into "Israel occupies..." in English. [[Google Translate]] is a [[Statistical machine translation|statistical translation engine]] that [[Google Translate#Translation mistakes and oddities|uses web search statistics rather than grammatical rules to yield a probable translation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0809/technology-computer-learning-google-translate.html|title=Forbes: Google Translate tangles with computer learning|author=Lee Gomes|date=July 22, 2010|publisher-Forbes}}</ref> Since "...occupies Israel" is a low-probability query owing to the fact that Israel has not been occupied and "Israel occupies..." is a higher-probability query on the other hand, the limitation of statistical translation results in the inaccurate translation.
â   â
===International reaction===
  â
{{Main|International reactions to the Egyptian Revolution of 2011}}
  â   â
International reactions have varied with most Western states saying peaceful protests should continue but also expressing concern for the stability of the country and the region. Many states in the region expressed concern and supported Mubarak, while others like Tunisia and Iran supported the protests. Israel was most cautious for change, with [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] asking his government ministers to maintain silence and urging Israel's US and European allies to curb their criticism of President Mubarak;<ref>{{cite news|title=Israel's Big Fears over a Post-Mubarak Egypt|url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/01/31/israels-big-fears-over-a-post-mubarak-egypt/|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[Euronews]]|date=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Israel Urges World To Curb Criticism of Egypt's Mubarak|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/israel-urges-world-to-curb-criticism-of-egypt-s-mubarak-1.340238|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=31 January 2011}}</ref> however, an [[Arab-Israeli]] parliamentarian supported the protests. There were also numerous solidarity protests for the anti-government protesters around the world.
  â   â
NGOs also expressed concern about the protests and the ensuing heavy-handed state response. Many countries also issued travel warnings or began evacuating their citizens. Even [[multinational corporation]]s began evacuating their [[expatriate]] workers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/|title=Foreign governments, businesses begin evacuations from Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
===Post-ousting===
  â
Amid the growing concerns for the country, on 21 February, [[David Cameron]], Prime Minister of the [[United Kingdom]], became the first world leader to visit Egypt since Mubarak was ousted as the president 10 days previously. A news blackout was lifted as the prime minister landed in Cairo for a brief five-hour stopover hastily added at the start of a planned tour of the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd |title=David Cameron visits Egypt â The Guardian |publisher=www.guardian.co.uk |accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref>
